stocks.note: *Numbers as of market close on Feb 17th
stocks.news:
By Sea Or By Land

A couple of big travel names flew (or sailed) higher yesterday.

Norwegian Cruise Lines (NCLH +12.15%) shares swelled on news that activist investor Elliott is taking a 10% stake in the company.

Southwest Airlines (LUV +6.16%) climbed to new 52-week highs on an upgrade from UBS (UBS +0.79%).

Big Swings In Big Tech:

The Mag 7 hasn't looked too magnificent in the past week, with the QQQs down nearly 2%.

But yesterday, Apple (AAPL +3.17%) traded higher as investors get more bullish on some of its AI products.

Amazon (AMZN +1.19%) also edged higher as traders bought the dip on the tech giant.

economy.commentary:
Goolsbee's Best Guess:

Chicago Fed President Goolsbee says 2026 could see "several" more rate cuts.

There's a catch: Only if inflation keeps cooling off, getting closer to the Fed's 2% target.

Goolsbee says services inflation (things like healthcare, housing, education) is rising, and the ongoing effects of tariffs are unknown.

A Tale Of Three Economies:

A new report from Bank of America shows that the U.S. economy is divided in three:
‚Ä¢ Wealthy spending is healthy: Up 2.5%, the highest rates since 2022.
‚Ä¢ Middle-income is flat: Spending is not moving up or down, wages up 1.6%.
‚Ä¢ Lower-income barely moving: Up 0.3%, and no wage data was collected.

real_estate.homebuilder:
Construction Confidence:

Home builders are not feeling great these days.

That's because an index tracking their confidence has dropped again, to 36, the lowest since September 2025.
‚Ä¢ Anything under 50 is considered "poor conditions" for home builders.

What's weighing it down? Tariffs increasing material costs, loss of labor pool due to immigration policy, and buyers just can't afford homes.

Banks Want Back In The Game:

Banks have been getting out of mortgage lending, down from 60% in 2008 to 35% today.
‚Ä¢ Why? Rules changed after the 2008 housing crisis, making it harder for banks to loan money.

So the Fed wants to change the rules again, to make it easier for banks to get back in the home loan game.
real_estate.commentary:
üìç Alameda County (Fremont Focus)

Fremont is currently outperforming its neighbors with stronger momentum than parts of Santa Clara County. While Silicon Valley (Santa Clara) is seeing a surprisingly slow start to the spring season with softening prices, Fremont (Alameda County) remains a competitive seller's market with rising demand and tight inventory.

Market Status - "Strong Seller's Market":

As of mid-February data, Fremont has an incredibly low 0.7 months of supply.
‚Ä¢ Competition: Homes are selling for roughly 101.7% of the asking price.
‚Ä¢ Speed: Average days on market is hovering around 45 days, but desirable single-family homes are moving much faster (often under 14 days).
‚Ä¢ Median Price: Trending between $1.38M and $1.69M, depending on the neighborhood.
‚Ä¢ Prices are Rising: Unlike its southern neighbor, Alameda County is seeing price growth. The median sale price is roughly $925,000, up 2.6% year-over-year.
‚Ä¢ Sales Volume is Down: Total sales have dropped about 8% compared to last year. This indicates a "gridlock" where buyers want to buy, but there simply aren't enough sellers listing their homes.
‚Ä¢ Buyer Behavior: Buyers are re-entering the market now (in February) rather than waiting for April/May, trying to beat the competition before interest rates potentially fluctuate again.
